Kitajska vlada ostro nad mladoletne ljubitelje spletnih iger!

07 Nov 2019, 12:50

Igranje iger preko spleta je za mnoge razvedrilo in priljubljen način zabave. Težave nastopijo, ker se igralci pogosto ne zavedajo, kdaj prestopijo mejo med igranjem zgolj za sprostitev in stanjem, ko so od igranja iger že odvisni. Zaradi prekomernega igranja računalniških iger lahko pride celo do izčrpanosti, ta pa vodi v smrt. Doslej je bilo zaradi igranja iger zabeleženih že več smrtnih primerov, kar ne preseneča, saj je odvisnost od igranja iger precej hujša od kajenja ali alkoholizma.
Ker je težava s prekomernim igranjem spletnih iger še posebno prisotna pri mladini na Kitajskem, je kitajska vlada sprejela vrsto ukrepov, ki naj bi odpravil ali pa vsaj omilil posledice prekomernega igranja iger ponoči. Ti namreč osebam mlajšim od 18 let prepovedujejo igranje spletih iger med deseto uro zvečer in osmo uro zjutraj. Omejitev igranja ponoči bo seveda veljala tudi za spletne kavarne, ki so med mladimi prav tako priljubljene, predvsem pa v nočnem času.
Mladoletni ljubitelji spletnih iger bodo lahko priljubljene igre ob delavnikih igrali do največ 90 minut na ta, za soboto in nedeljo ter državne praznike pa je omejitev postavljena na tri ure dnevno. Kitajska vlada je za nameček omejila tudi količino denarja, ki se lahko porabi za namene spletnih iger. Mlajši od 16 let bodo lahko mesečno za spletne igre namenili do preračunanih 26,88 evrov, mladi starosti med 16 let in 18 let pa bodo lahko mesečno »zapravili« do preračunanih 53,76 evrov. Mlajšim od osem let pa je nakupovanje v spletnih igrah celo prepovedano.
Nadzor nad uporabniki spletnih iger se bo izvajal tudi preko edinstvene identifikacijske številke, ki jo morajo uporabniki iger vnesti pred pričetkom spletnih iger. Če pa programerji te omejitve ne upoštevajo, jih lahko doleti tako visoka denarna kazen kot celo zapor. Učitelji na Kitajskem novi vladne ukrepe v večini podpirajo, saj kar precej otrok zaradi odvisnosti od svetovnega spleta ne več obiskuje pouka, ne spi in se le redko prehranjuje, zato ne preseneča, da smrtni primeri zaradi prekomernega igranja spletnih iger na Kitajskem niso več nobena redkost.
Po ocenah različnih analitskih hiš na Kitajskem spletne igre prekomerno igra že okoli 200 milijonov otrok in mladostnikov. Ali bo nova zakonodaja pripomogla k zmanjšanju odvisnosti mladih od igranja spletnih iger, pa bo seveda pokazal čas. Mnogi poznavalci so sicer prepričani, da bo zakon v praksi zelo težko izvajati, čeprav Kitajska ima dolgoletne izkušnje z omejevanjem pravic ljudi do dostopa do svetovnega spleta.

Chinese rule harshly against underage online gaming lovers!

07 Nov 2019, 11:50

Playing games online is a fun and popular way of entertainment for many. Problems arise because players are often unaware of when they cross the line between playing solely for relaxation and the state when they are already dependent on playing games. Excessive computer gaming can even lead to exhaustion, which can lead to death. So far, many deaths have been reported as a result of playing games, which is not surprising since addiction to playing games is much more severe than smoking or alcoholism.
As the problem of over-playing online games is particularly prevalent among youth in China, the Chinese government has taken a series of measures to address, or at least mitigate, the consequences of over-playing games at night. These are forbidden to anyone under the age of 18 to play online games between ten in the evening and eight in the morning. The restriction on playing at night will, of course, apply to online cafes, which are also popular with young people, but especially at night.
Minor online game lovers will be able to play popular games on weekdays up to a maximum of 90 minutes per week, with a limit of three hours per day for Saturdays and Sundays and public holidays. The Chinese government has also limited the amount of money that can be spent for online gaming purposes. Under 16s will be able to spend up to $ 26.88 a month for online games, while young people between the ages of 16 and 18 can spend up to $ 53.76 a month for online games. Under the age of eight, however, shopping in online games is even prohibited.
Supervision of online gaming users will also be exercised through a unique identification number that gaming users must enter before online gaming begins. However, if developers do not comply with these restrictions, they can face as high a fine as prison. Teachers in China are overwhelmingly supportive of new government measures, as many children are no longer attending classes, sleeping and seldom eating because of addiction to the World Wide Web, so it is no surprise that over-playing deaths in China are no longer uncommon .
According to estimates by various think tanks in China, about 200 million children and adolescents are playing too many online games. Whether the new legislation will help reduce young people's dependence on playing online games will, of course, show time. Many connoisseurs are convinced that the law will be very difficult to put into practice, even though China has many years of experience restricting people's rights to access the World Wide Web.
